revision.text:
{{Infobox dot-com company | company_name = 10 Minute School | logo = 10minutesschool.png | company_type = | traded_as = | foundation = | dissolved = | location = Software Technology Park, Janata Tower, [[Karwan Bazar]], [[Dhaka]] | locations = | incorporated = | founded = {{Start date and age|2015|5}} in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] | area_served = Bangladesh | founder = | chairman = | chairperson = | president = | CEO = Ayman Sadiq <small>(founder)</small> | MD = | GM = | key_people = | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | url = {{URL|www.10minuteschool.com}} | programming_language = | ipv6 = | alexa = {{Decrease}} 206 <small>(Rank in Bangladesh)</small> ({{As of|2018|8|1}})<ref name=Alexa2018>{{cite web|url=https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/10minuteschool.com|title=10 minute school Traffic Statistics|publisher=[[Alexa Internet|Alexa Internet, Inc.]]|year=2018}}</ref> | website_type = Education Technology Company | advertising = | registration = Optional | num_users = | language = Bengali, English | launch_date = | current_status = Active | screenshot = | caption = | footnotes = | intl = |name=10 Minute School}} '''10 Minute School''' ({{Lang-bn|১০ মিনিট স্কুল}}, abbreviated as '''10MS''') is an [[Online tutoring|online educational platform]] in [[Bangladesh]] created in 2015 by internet entrepreneur Ayman Sadiq.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sdasia.co/2015/06/20/10-minute-school-learn-practice-progress/|title=10 Minute School: Learn, Practice, Progress - SDAsia|date=2015-06-20|work=SDAsia|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The platform covers academic classes from classes 1 to 12 covering the entire academic syllabus of the Bangladesh schooling system, university admission subjects covering different branches of study, and skills training.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://10minuteschool.com/|title=The Largest Educational Platform in Bangladesh|website=10 Minute School|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref>
== History ==
Ayman Sadiq founded 10 Minute School in mid 2014 as an YouTube Channel.<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.intellect.com.bd/details/343/-%E2%80%9Clearn.-practice.-progress.%E2%80%9D |title="Learn. Practice. Progress." |last= intellect.com.bd |work= Intellect.com.bd |access-date=2018-03-03 |language= en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.observerbd.com/details.php?id=80508|title=Ayman Sadiq & his 10 Minute School - Young Observer - observerbd.com|work=The Daily Observer|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.observerbd.com/2015/05/29/91349.php|title=10 minutes for e-learning|website=www.observerbd.com|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref> Largely self-sponsored in the beginning, 10 Minute School did not initially have a website and solely reached students through educational info graphics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.slideshare.net/10_Minute_School/infographics|title=10 Minute School Infographics on SlideShare|website=www.slideshare.net|language=en|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.slideshare.net/10_Minute_School/infographics|title=10 Minute School Infographics on SlideShare|website=www.slideshare.net|language=en|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref> It started creating video tutorials for [[Mathematics]] and [[English studies|English]] and eventually started taking live classes on Facebook.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/dhakatribune/docs/150530195646-84313fd8266843be9c3593810841c481/22|title=31 May, 2015|work=Issuu|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/dhakatribune/docs/150530195646-84313fd8266843be9c3593810841c481/22|title=31 May, 2015|work=Issuu|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en}}</ref> 10 Minute School went on to cover the entire academic syllabus from [[First grade|Class 1]] through [[Twelfth grade|Class12]], university admission subjects covering topics from public and private university examinations and extensive software and skills training.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.observerbd.com/2015/05/29/91349.php|title=10 minutes for e-learning|website=www.observerbd.com|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref>
While one of the major challenges for the organization back then was to find a suitable sponsor to fund its operational activities, it later came to be supported by telecom operator [[Robi|Robi Axiata]] Ltd and the [[Ministry of Posts, Telecommunications and Information Technology|ICT Ministry of Bangladesh]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.daily-sun.com/post/198758/ICT-Div-Robi-10-Minute-School-join-hands-to-promote-digital-edu|title=ICT Div, Robi, 10 Minute School join hands to promote digital edu {{!}} daily sun|last=Sun|first=The Daily|date=|work=Daily Sun|access-date=2018-03-03|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
== Contents == As of July 2018, the website produced 4000 [[video lesson]]s, 100 [[Smartbook|SmartBooks]], 3965 [[quiz]]zes and 255 live classes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1207416/lifestyle|title=Bangladesh’s 10 Minute School wins another award|date=2017-12-11|work=Arab News|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Education in Bangladesh]]

{{Use Irish English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2010 student protests in Dublin | partof = [[Anti-austerity protests in Ireland]] | image = Education Not Emigration National March 3 November 2010 Poster.jpg | caption = "Education Not Emigration" | date = 3 November 2010 | place = [[Dublin]], Ireland | coordinates = | causes = | methods = | side1 = | side2 = | side3 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | fatalities = | injuries = | casualties_label = | notes = }} The '''2010 student protest in Dublin''' was a [[Demonstration (people)|demonstration]] that took place in the centre of the city on 3 November 2010 in opposition to a proposed increase in university registration fees, further cuts to the student maintenance grant and increasing graduate unemployment and emigration levels caused by the [[Government of the 30th Dáil#28th Government of Ireland|28th Government of Ireland]].<ref name="USI">{{cite news|url=http://www.usi.ie/press-archives/65-2010/1546-thousands-of-students-expected-at-usi-protest-march.html |title=Over 25,000 Students Expected at USI Protest March |date=3 November 2010 |work=[[Union of Students in Ireland]] |accessdate=3 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721135212/http://www.usi.ie/press-archives/65-2010/1546-thousands-of-students-expected-at-usi-protest-march.html |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Organized by the [[Union of Students in Ireland]] (USI) and students unions nationwide, it saw between 25,000 and 40,000 protesters on the streets of central Dublin during what ''[[The Irish Times]]'' described as "the largest student protest for a generation".<ref name="25,000 protest against fees increase">{{cite news|author=Flynn, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1104/1224282635055.html|title=25,000 protest against fees increase|date=4 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> The protestors came from all over Ireland – students from most third-level colleges featured, as did some protestors from [[Queen's University Belfast]]<ref name="QUB students join Dublin fees protest"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Pearl, Aine|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-517840?ref=feeds%2Foncnn|title=Irish Student Protest|date=11 November 2010|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=11 November 2010}}</ref> – with many travelling to the city by coach.<ref name="25,000 protest against fees increase"/> It took more than an hour and a half for all the protestors to walk from [[Parnell Square]] to [[Government Buildings]] in [[Merrion Street]], a short distance.<ref name="25,000 protest against fees increase"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=47453&locID=1.2.&pagename=news |title=Thousands of students expected to protest |date=3 November 2010 |work=[[TV3 News]] |publisher=[[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] |accessdate=3 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329042436/http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=47453&locID=1.2.&pagename=news |archivedate=29 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Some protestors and [[Garda Síochána|gardaí]] engaged in clashes following the protest, with an unidentified number of people being wounded and three gardaí sustaining minor injuries; two arrests were made.<ref name="Gardaí, students clash in Dublin">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/1103/education.html|title=Gardaí, students clash in Dublin|date=3 November 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]|accessdate=3 November 2010}}</ref> The two men who were arrested were in their twenties and charged with [[criminal damage]] and a [[breach of the peace]] respectively.<ref name="Gardaí, students clash in Dublin"/> The [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Department of Finance]] was occupied by protestors for a time, and 36 complaints of [[police brutality]] were made of which just over half were admitted;<ref name="Garda Ombudsman">{{cite web|url=http://www.gardaombudsman.ie/GSOC/121110-Complaints-arising-from-incidents-associated-with-the-student-protest-in-Dublin-on-3rd-November-2010.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721124428/http://www.gardaombudsman.ie/GSOC/121110-Complaints-arising-from-incidents-associated-with-the-student-protest-in-Dublin-on-3rd-November-2010.pdf |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> these led to a further march by students seven days later with the intention to "end garda brutality".<ref name="Up to 500 students protest over Garda behaviour"/>
[[Presseurop]] wondered the day after thousands of students marched on the streets of Dublin: "Has Ireland awoken?" and said the protest had "Giv[en] the lie to general opinion that the economically stricken nation has taken swingeing austerity measures with passive resignation".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.presseurop.eu/en/content/news-brief-cover/376801-has-ireland-awoken|title=Has Ireland awoken?|date=4 November 2010|work=[[Presseurop]]|accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> [[2010 student protest in London|"Scenes bizarrely similar"]] occurred in [[London]] one week later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/sound-familiar-student-protest-in-london-turns-nasty-2010-11/|title=Sound familiar? Student protest in London turns nasty|date=10 November 2010|publisher=thejournal.ie|accessdate=10 November 2010}}</ref>
==Background== The [[BBC]]'s Ireland Correspondent [[Mark Simpson (Ireland Correspondent)|Mark Simpson]] noted that most demonstrations in Ireland had been "angry rather than violent".<ref name="Irish government comes under fire from students"/> One example he alluded to occurred two days before students demonstrated when [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health and Children]] [[Mary Harney]] was successfully pelted with red paint by an opposition politician in a protest intended to highlight the "blood budget" which "will result in the unnecessary and avoidable deaths of hundreds, if not thousands, of people over the coming years"; this incident occurred while she was attempting to open a mental healthcare facility in Dublin.<ref name="Irish government comes under fire from students"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/World/Story/STIStory_598214.html|title=Irish minister pelted with paint|date=1 November 2010|work=[[The Straits Times]]|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]|accessdate=1 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory?id=12022960|title=Irish Health Minister Pelted With Paint Over Cuts: Ireland's health minister pelted with red paint as protesters decry plans to slash health jobs|date=1 November 2010|work=[[ABC News]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|accessdate=1 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/1101/harneym.html|title=Councillor quizzed over Harney paint incident|date=1 November 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]|accessdate=1 November 2010}}</ref> But Simpson also wrote that "It is unlikely that their [students] demonstration will make any difference. [...] They [the Irish government] will be hoping that young people will eventually accept [that Ireland has no money]. After all, most students know what it feels like to be broke".<ref name="Irish government comes under fire from students"/>
==March and further events== According to ''The Irish Times'', the protest was "powerful, uplifting – and very peaceful".<ref>{{cite news|author1=Nihill, Cían |author2=Flynn, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1106/1224282790865.html|title=What our reporters saw|date=6 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=6 November 2010}}</ref> It commenced from [[Parnell Square]] at 13:00.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events">{{cite news|author1=Nihill, Cían |author2=Flynn, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1104/1224282635068.html|title=Student march: timeline of events|date=4 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> T-shirts bearing slogans such as "Education not Emigration" were worn by many protestors.<ref name="Irish government comes under fire from students">{{cite news|author=[[Mark Simpson (Ireland Correspondent)|Simpson, Mark]]|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11689264|title=Irish government comes under fire from students|date=3 November 2010|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=3 November 2010}}</ref> Students from [[Queen's University Belfast]] joined their counterparts on the streets of Dublin for the protest in return for support given to their own protest at [[Parliament Buildings (Northern Ireland)|Stormont]] two days earlier.<ref name="QUB students join Dublin fees protest">{{cite news|author=Rutherford, Fiona |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/community-telegraph/south-belfast/news/qub-students-join-dublin-fees-protest-14995288.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419194131/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/community-telegraph/south-belfast/news/qub-students-join-dublin-fees-protest-14995288.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 April 2013 |title=QUB students join Dublin fees protest |date=4 November 2010 |work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] |accessdate=4 November 2010 }}</ref> Forty minutes later, some protestors left the march route at [[Nassau Street (Dublin)|Nassau Street]] and approached [[Dáil Éireann]]'s front gates on [[Kildare Street]].<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> Some scaled poles and items were thrown through the gates.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> March organisers sent them back to the main protest.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/>
Several dozen protestors entered the [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Department of Finance]]'s lobby at 15:00 and commenced occupation.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> Authorities removed some and barricaded the remainder inside.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> More students gathered outside the entrance where authorities lined up to separate them from those inside the building, while horses and vans were deployed to split those outside into two.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> A sit-down protest ensued among those who were outside.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> [[Riot police]] arrived on the scene and authorities removed the rest of the protestors still inside the building, some of whom had "evidence of a beating on their faces" (''The Irish Times'').<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> Riot police then forced those outside to move backwards, eventually charging at them followed by horses and dogs until they reached the [[Shelbourne Hotel]].<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> A second charge by the authorities forced those in the vicinity back to [[Anglo Irish Bank]].<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/>
Many of those left outside the Department of Finance then joined a peaceful sit-down protest which was occurring outside Dáil Éireann.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> [[Free Education for Everyone]] then organised a march to [[Pearse Street]] garda station, thought to be the destination of those who had been arrested.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/> They collected there and demanded the release of anyone who had been arrested.<ref name="Student march: timeline of events"/>
==Complaints of police brutality== Two female protesters were reported to have been pulled out of the Department of Finance "by their ankles" and one by her hair.<ref name="Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets"/> One bespectacled male student was trampled upon by a horse.<ref name="Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets"/> A female was kicked and knocked to the ground by a horse.<ref name="Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets"/> Another who said she was engaging in a peaceful protest was told by police to "get the fuck off the street" before being batoned.<ref name="Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets">{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/student-protest-brings-chaos-to-dublin-streets-14995269.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419203032/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/student-protest-brings-chaos-to-dublin-streets-14995269.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 April 2013 |title=Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets |date=4 November 2010 |work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] |accessdate=4 November 2010 }}</ref> A male sitting peacefully on the ground with his hands out was reported to have been "rammed" by four garda horses.<ref name="Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets"/> Blood and facial injuries were a common sight.<ref name="Student protest brings chaos to Dublin streets"/>
After viewing video footage of the disorder [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] [[Joe Higgins]] said: "The use of Garda horses and dogs against student protesters in Dublin on Wednesday is an outrageous abuse of the right to protest. The intention was clearly to intimidate peaceful protesters and it is an utter scandal. They should never again be used against protesters".<ref>{{cite news|author=Lally, Conor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/1105/breaking43.html|title=Complaints over protest policing|date=5 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref>
These events led to numerous complaints about police brutality being sent to the [[Garda Síochána Ombudsman Commission]] (GSOC).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/1105/demonstration.html|title=Complaints over student demonstration policing|date=5 November 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=47578&locID=1.2.&pagename=news |title=Ombudsman receives Garda complaints |date=3 November 2010 |work=[[TV3 News]] |publisher=[[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] |accessdate=3 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329042441/http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=47578&locID=1.2.&pagename=news |archivedate=29 March 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Lally, Conor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1106/1224282790804.html|title=Complaints on policing of protest to be reviewed|date=6 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=6 November 2010}}</ref> Within days the number of complaints had more than doubled.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/1109/education.html|title=28 complaints over gardaí behaviour|date=9 November 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]|accessdate=9 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Black, Fergus|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/protest-sparks-28-complaints-2413761.html|title=Protest sparks 28 complaints|date=10 November 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=10 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Carr, Aoife|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/1109/breaking20.html|title=Protest policing complaints double|date=9 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=9 November 2010}}</ref> Video footage taken by witnesses was to be examined.<ref>{{cite news|author=Hickey, Shane|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/garda-watchdog-to-examine-footage-of-protests-2409945.html|title=Garda watchdog to examine footage of protests|date=6 November 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=6 November 2010}}</ref>
On 10 November, hundreds of students marched through Dublin again, this time before the banner "END GARDA BRUTALITY".<ref name="Up to 500 students protest over Garda behaviour">{{cite news|author=Duncan, Pamela|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1111/1224283092895.html|title=Up to 500 students protest over Garda behaviour|date=11 November 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=11 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/1110/education.html|title=Students protest against garda 'brutality'|date=10 November 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]|accessdate=10 November 2010}}</ref> ''The Irish Times'' stated that "While members of the [[Socialist Workers Party (Ireland)|Socialist Worker Student Society]] and the [[32 County Sovereignty Movement]] were present at last night’s protest, they made up only a small proportion of the crowd".<ref name="Up to 500 students protest over Garda behaviour"/> Among the protestors was Vanessa O'Sullivan, video footage of whom unconscious was broadcast on [[YouTube]] and [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]].<ref name="Up to 500 students protest over Garda behaviour"/> She told the crowd: "This day last week I was knocked unconscious by a gárda... All I am guilty of is walking inside a public building and sitting down".<ref name="Up to 500 students protest over Garda behaviour"/>
==See also== * [[2011 United Kingdom protests]] * [[March for a Better Way]] * [[2010 UK student protests]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1104/1224282635068.html ''The Irish Times'' – "Student march: timeline of events"] * [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1104/1224282635120.html "Critical views: 'I can understand cuts, but education is a stupid one'"] *[http://www.herald.ie/national-news/city-news/soon-everyone-will-be-too-frightened-to-make-a-public-protest-2407202.html ''Evening Herald'' – "Soon everyone will be too frightened to make a public protest"]
