revision.text:
{{Intelligent Design}} {{Education in the U.S.}} {{use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} A number of [[anti-evolution]] [[bill (proposed law)|bills]] have been introduced in the [[United States Congress]] and [[State legislature (United States)|State legislatures]] since 2001. Purporting to support [[academic freedom]], supporters have contended that teachers, students, and college professors face intimidation and retaliation when discussing scientific criticisms of evolution, and therefore require protection.<ref>{{harvnb|Discovery Institute|2007}}</ref> Critics of the legislation have pointed out that there are no credible scientific critiques of evolution.{{sfn|Simon|2008}} An investigation in [[Florida]] of the allegations of intimidation and retaliation found no evidence that it had occurred.{{sfn|The Professional Staff of the Education Pre-K-12 Committee|2008}} The vast majority of the bills have been unsuccessful, with the one exception being Louisiana's [[Louisiana Science Education Act]], which was enacted in 2008.
Based largely upon language drafted by the [[Discovery Institute]], from language originally drafted for the [[Santorum Amendment]], the common goal of these bills has been to expose more students to articles and videos that criticize evolution, most of which have been produced by advocates of [[intelligent design]] or Biblical [[creationism]].<ref>{{harvnb|Simon|2008}}</ref>
==Santorum Amendment== [[File:Rick Santorum official photo.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Rick Santorum]], sponsor of the [[Santorum Amendment]]]] {{main|Santorum Amendment}} In 2001 former [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] [[Rick Santorum]] from [[Pennsylvania]] proposed an amendment, to the education funding bill which became known as the [[No Child Left Behind Act]], which promoted the teaching of intelligent design while questioning the academic standing of [[evolution]] in U.S. public schools.<ref>{{harvnb|U.S. Congress|2001}}</ref> The language of this amendment was crafted in part by the Discovery Institute's Center for Science and Culture, with [[Phillip E. Johnson]], founding adviser of the Discovery Institute's Center for Science and Culture, and "father" of the intelligent design movement, assisting Santorum in phrasing the amendment.<ref>{{harvnb|Cromartie|2005}}, That language, which was penned by Phil Johnson for Rick Santorum, passed the Senate as an amendment to the No Child Left Behind education bill, and eventually became part of the conference report for that legislation.</ref>{{sfn|Santorum|2002}} It portrayed evolution as generating "much continuing controversy" and being not widely accepted, using the Discovery Institute's [[Teach The Controversy]] method.{{sfn|Orr|2005}}<ref>{{harvnb|Pasulka|2012}}</ref>
{{quote|The Conferees recognize that a quality science education should prepare students to distinguish the data and testable theories of science from religious or philosophical claims that are made in the name of science. Where topics are taught that may generate controversy (such as biological evolution), the curriculum should help students to understand the full range of scientific views that exist, why such topics may generate controversy, and how scientific discoveries can profoundly affect society.|Final text of the Santorum Amendment as included in the Conference Report.{{sfn|House of Representatives|2001}} }}
On June 14, 2001, the amendment was passed as part of the education funding bill by the Senate on a vote of 91-8. This was hailed as a major victory by proponents of intelligent design; for instance an email newsletter by the Discovery Institute contained the sentence "Undoubtedly this will change the face of the debate over the theories of evolution and intelligent design in America ... It also seems that the Darwinian monopoly on public science education, and perhaps the biological sciences in general, is ending."<ref>{{harvnb|Foerstel|2009|p=163}}</ref>
Scientists and educators feared that by singling out biological evolution as very controversial, the amendment could create the impression that a substantial scientific controversy about evolution exists, leading to a lessening of academic rigor in science curricula. A coalition of 96 scientific and educational organizations signed a letter urging that the amendment be stricken from the final bill, which it was, but intelligent design supporters on the conference committee preserved it in the bill's legislative history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.issues.org/18.3/hill.html |title=Language on evolution attached to education law |date=Spring 2002 |publisher=The National Academys |location=Washington, D.C. |page="From the Hill" |accessdate=2010-06-08 |ref=harv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710130329/http://www.issues.org/18.3/hill.html |archive-date=July 10, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Overview== {{See also|Intelligent design in politics}} Rather than calling for teaching intelligent design or Bible-based [[creationism]] (as previous legislative attempts have), the bills make no mention of these subjects. They instead describe evolution as controversial and attempt to bar school administrators from interfering with teachers who describe purported flaws in the theory. This runs contrary to the overwhelming scientific consensus, which holds that there is no debate about the core principles of evolution: the only credible, and a thoroughly tested, scientific explanation for the development and diversification of all life on Earth.<ref name=EdWeek>{{cite web |url = http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2008/05/14/37evolution_ep.h27.html?tmp=1673105826 |title = 'Academic Freedom' Used as Basis Of Bills to Question Evolution |first = Sean |last = Cavanagh |date = May 12, 2008 |publisher = Education Week: Editorial Projects in Education |accessdate = 2010-06-08 |ref = harv }}{{subscription}}</ref>
Tom Hutton, a senior staff lawyer for the [[National School Boards Association]], stated that while state legislators have a legal right to craft laws that affect districts' policies as a general rule, he believes that some decisions are better left to local officials. He further suggested that these proposed bills, if enacted, could face difficult legal challenges. He further stated that despite their language stating that they are not promoting religious views, and wording to promote "scientific" rather than religious critiques, courts are likely to question the motives behind these bills, and their specific focus on evolution, and draw a conclusion as to "what's going on here."<ref name=EdWeek />
Michael Simpson, a lawyer for the [[National Education Association]] stated that courts have generally refused to afford significant free-speech protections to teachers for in-class remarks. He further offered the opinion that the legality of these measures would depend on a number of unknowns, such as how the critical views of evolution-critical views were presented, and possibly the degree of congruence between them and other state policies, such as state science curriculum.<ref name=EdWeek/>
A variety of groups, such as the [[National Center for Science Education]] and [[Anti-Defamation League]], criticized and are publicly opposed to the "Academic Freedom bills."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/07/adl-reiterates-its-support-evolution-education-002132 |title=ADL reiterates its support of evolution education |author=[[National Center for Science Education]] |date=July 22, 2008 |publisher=self published newsletter |accessdate=2010-06-09 |ref=harv |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100427203846/http://ncse.com/news/2008/07/adl-reiterates-its-support-evolution-education-002132 |archivedate= 27 April 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19926643.300-new-legal-threat-to-school-science-in-the-us.html?DCMP=ILC-hmts&nsref=news3_head_mg19926643.300 |title=New legal threat to teaching evolution in the US |first=Amanda |last=Gefter |date=July 9, 2008 |publisher=[[New Scientist]] |accessdate=2010-06-09 |ref=harv}}{{subscription}}</ref>
==Alabama bills== Between 2004 and 2006, a series of unsuccessful anti-evolution 'Academic freedom' bills were introduced in the [[Alabama Legislature]].<ref name=NCSE_Flr1>{{cite web |url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/164/opposition-to-the-antievolution-bills-in-florida |title=Opposition to the bills in Florida |author=[[National Center for Science Education]] |date=March 19, 2008 |accessdate=2010-06-09 |ref=harv |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100427201906/http://ncse.com/news/2008/164/opposition-to-the-antievolution-bills-in-florida |archivedate= 27 April 2010 }}</ref>
On April 8, 2004, the [[Alabama Senate]] unanimously passed SB336, the "Academic Freedom Act." The bill would have given teachers at public institutions "the affirmative right and freedom to present scientific, historical, theoretical, or evidentiary information pertaining to alternative theories or points of view on the subject of origins" and gives students the right to hold a "particular position on origins, so long as he or she demonstrates acceptable understanding of course materials." Before passage, it was amended so that "[t]he rights and privileges contained in this act do not apply to the presentation of theoretical information unless it is accompanied by scientific, historical, or evidentiary information."<ref name=NCSE_Ala1>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2004/04/academic-freedom-act-progresses-alabama-00481|title='Academic Freedom Act' progresses in Alabama |first=Nick|last=Matzke |date=April 16, 2004|publisher=[[National Center for Science Education]] |accessdate=2010-06-09 |ref=harv |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131551/http://ncse.com/news/2004/04/academic-freedom-act-progresses-alabama-00481|archivedate=28 April 2010 }}</ref> On May 17, 2004, the [[Alabama House]] adjourned the 2004 legislative session without voting on the bill, allowing it to lapse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2004/05/alabama-legislature-lets-sb336-die-without-vote-00484|title=Alabama legislature lets SB336 die without a vote|first=Nick|last=Matzke|date=May 18, 2004|publisher=[[National Center for Science Education]]|accessdate=2010-06-09|ref=harv|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131118/http://ncse.com/news/2004/05/alabama-legislature-lets-sb336-die-without-vote-00484|archivedate= 28 April 2010 }}</ref>
On February 8, 2005, a pair of virtually identical bills were simultaneously introduced in the Alabama Senate and House (HB352 and SB240), again under the description of "The Academic Freedom Act." These bills purported to protect the right of teachers "to present scientific critiques of prevailing scientific theories" and the right of students to "hold positions regarding scientific views". In an attempt to avert Establishment Clause concerns, the bills both stated that "[n]othing in this act shall be construed as promoting any religious doctrine, promoting discrimination for or against a particular set of religious beliefs, or promoting discrimination for or against religion or non-religion."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2005/02/alternative-theories-legislation-again-00569|title="Alternative Theories" Legislation – Again|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=February 10, 2005|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131012/http://ncse.com/news/2005/02/alternative-theories-legislation-again-00569|archivedate= 28 April 2010|ref=harv}}</ref> On April 5, 2005, a third, near-identical bill (also dubbed the "Academic Freedom Act") was introduced in the Alabama House (HB 716).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2005/04/third-2005-antievolution-bill-introduced-alabama-00570|title=Third 2005 Antievolution Bill Introduced in Alabama|first=Nick|last=Matzke|date=April 19, 2005|publisher=[[National Center for Science Education]]|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428130913/http://ncse.com/news/2005/04/third-2005-antievolution-bill-introduced-alabama-00570|archivedate= 28 April 2010|ref=harv}}</ref> On May 3, 2005, the legislative session closed without passing any of these three bills, so that they lapsed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2005/05/three-antievolution-bills-die-alabama-00572|title=Three antievolution bills die in Alabama|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=May 5, 2005|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131216/http://ncse.com/news/2005/05/three-antievolution-bills-die-alabama-00572|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref>
On January 10, 2006, another pair of identical anti-evolution bills (HB106 and SB45), closely resembling the previous bills, were introduced in the Alabama legislature, again under the description of "The Academic Freedom Act".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/two-antievolution-bills-alabama-00785|title=Two antievolution bills in Alabama |author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=January 21, 2006|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428003424/http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/two-antievolution-bills-alabama-00785|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref> On April 18, 2006 the Alabama Legislature again adjourned without passing them, again allowing them to lapse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/05/alabama-antievolution-bills-die-00784|title=Alabama antievolution bills die|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=May 10, 2006|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428130645/http://ncse.com/news/2006/05/alabama-antievolution-bills-die-00784|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref>
On April 24, 2008, David Grimes introduced an 'Academic Freedom' bill (HB 923) into the Alabama House and it was referred to the Education Policy Committee.<ref name="National Center for Science Education">{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/antievolution-legislation-alabama-004280|title=Antievolution legislation in Alabama|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=February 6, 2009|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428111645/http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/antievolution-legislation-alabama-004280|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref> It died in committee on May 7.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/antievolution-legislation-alabama-004280|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100428111645/http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/antievolution-legislation-alabama-004280|dead-url=yes|archive-date=April 28, 2010|title=Alabama antievolution bill dies|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=May 8, 2008|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2018-01-10|ref=harv}}</ref>
On February 3, 2009, Grimes introduced another 'Academic Freedom' bill (HB 300) which was again referred to the House Education Policy Committee.<ref name="National Center for Science Education"/> It died in committee with the end of the legislative session on May 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/05/alabama-antievolution-bill-dies-004781|title=Alabama antievolution bill dies|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=May 15, 2009|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428111515/http://ncse.com/news/2009/05/alabama-antievolution-bill-dies-004781|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref>
==Oklahoma bills== In early 2006 Representative [[Sally Kern]] introduced an anti-evolution 'Academic Freedom' bill (HB2107) into the [[Oklahoma House]], which passed it by a vote of 77-10 on March 2, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/antievolution-legislation-horizon-oklahoma-00886|title=Antievolution legislation on the horizon in Oklahoma|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=January 12, 2006|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131528/http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/antievolution-legislation-horizon-oklahoma-00886|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/03/oklahoma-update-00892|title=Oklahoma update|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=March 30, 2006|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131345/http://ncse.com/news/2006/03/oklahoma-update-00892|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref> Also in 2006 Senator Daisy Lawler introduced another anti-evolution bill, based upon language in the Santorum Amendment, in the [[Oklahoma Senate]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/third-antievolution-bill-oklahoma-00889|title=A third antievolution bill in Oklahoma|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=January 24, 2006|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131034/http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/third-antievolution-bill-oklahoma-00889|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref> Both bills (and two further, unrelated, anti-evolution bills) lapsed with the end of the 2006 legislative session.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/06/respite-oklahoma-00893|title=Respite in Oklahoma|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=June 29, 2006|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131517/http://ncse.com/news/2006/06/respite-oklahoma-00893|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref>
In February 2009 a bill titled the 'Scientific Education and Academic Freedom Act' (SB 320) was introduced by Senator [[Randy Brogdon]] and died in committee the Oklahoma Senate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/oklahoma-antievolution-bill-dead-004309 |title=Oklahoma antievolution bill dead|author= [[National Center for Science Education]]|date= February 17, 2009|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tulsabeacon.com/?p=1582 |title=Senate Rejects Academic Freedom Bill |first=Randy |last=Brogdon |newspaper=Tulsa Beacon |date=12 March 2009 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717112347/http://www.tulsabeacon.com/?p=1582 |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://webserver1.lsb.state.ok.us/2009-10bills/SB/sb320_int.rtf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123123917/http://webserver1.lsb.state.ok.us/2009-10bills/SB/sb320_int.rtf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-01-23 |title=SB 320 |ref=harv }}</ref> The bill is nearly identical to the [[#Louisiana act|Act passed in 2008 in Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oklascience.org/SB320_handout.pdf |title=Oppose SB 320 |publisher=Oklahomans for Excellence in Science Education |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726165334/http://www.oklascience.org/SB320_handout.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-26 |df= }}</ref>
==Maryland bill== A bill (HB1531) was introduced into the [[Maryland House of Delegates]] on February 16, 2006, to enact a "Teachers Academic Freedom Act" and a "Faculty Academic Freedom Act", that closely resembled the 2006 Alabama bills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/02/antievolution-legislation-maryland-00827|title=Antievolution legislation in Maryland|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=February 21, 2006|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428130523/http://ncse.com/news/2006/02/antievolution-legislation-maryland-00827|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref> The bill lapsed with the end of the 2006 legislative session.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/03/both-antievolution-bills-mississippi-now-dead-00842|title=Both antievolution bills in Maryland dead|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=March 3, 2006|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-09|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100429014232/http://ncse.com/news/2006/03/both-antievolution-bills-mississippi-now-dead-00842|archivedate= 29 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref>
==New Mexico bills== In January 2007, two identical bills (HB 506 and SB 371) "relating to public education; providing for school science content standards and rules regarding the teaching of theories of biological origins" were introduced into the [[New Mexico Legislature]] and [[New Mexico Senate|Senate]] by Representative W. C. "Dub" Williams and Senator Steve Komadina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2007/01/antievolution-legislation-new-mexico-00110|title=Antievolution legislation in New Mexico|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=January 31, 2007|publisher=self published newsletter|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmlegis.gov/Sessions/07%20Regular/bills/house/HB0506.html|title=HB 506|first=W. C. "Dub"|last=Williams|date=January 24, 2007|publisher=[[New Mexico Legislature]]|work=primary source|accessdate=2010-06-10|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmlegis.gov/Sessions/07%20Regular/bills/senate/SB0371.html|title=SB 371|first=Steve|last=Komadina|date=January 23, 2007|publisher=[[New Mexico Senate]]|work=primary source|accessdate=2010-06-10|ref=harv}}</ref> The bills died with the end of legislative session on March 17, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2007/03/antievolution-measures-dead-new-mexico-001107|title=Antievolution measures dead in New Mexico|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=March 22, 2007|accessdate=2010-06-10|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428131442/http://ncse.com/news/2007/03/antievolution-measures-dead-new-mexico-001107|archivedate= 28 April 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref>
In February 2009, an identical bill was again introduced, this time by Senator Kent L. Cravens in the New Mexico Senate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmlegis.gov/lcs/_session.aspx?chamber=S&legtype=B&legno=%20433&year=09 |title=2009 Regular Session (SB 433) |first=Kent L. |last=Cravens |date=February 2, 2009 |publisher=[[New Mexico Legislature]] |accessdate=2010-06-10 |work=primary source |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721060001/http://www.nmlegis.gov/lcs/_session.aspx?chamber=S&legtype=B&legno=%20433&year=09 |archivedate=July 21, 2011 }}</ref> Although it does not mention the phrase "academic freedom", the [[National Center for Science Education]] described the bill as "clearly in the mold of the recent spate of anti-evolution 'academic freedom' bills".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/antievolution-legislation-new-mexico-004272 |title=Antievolution legislation in New Mexico |publisher=[[National Center for Science Education]] |date=February 3, 2009 |accessdate=2012-06-23}}</ref> A Public Education Department analysis of the bill found that "[a]lthough the bill's definition of 'scientific information' excludes information derived from religious or philosophical writings, beliefs or doctrines", the bill "goes on to say that scientific information may have religious or philosophical implications and remain scientific in nature", which led to the conclusion that "this point would allow the teaching of theories of biological origins such as intelligent design or creationism."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.nmlegis.gov/Sessions/09%20Regular/LESCAnalysis/SB0433.pdf |title=Bill analysis, SB 433|publisher= Legislative Education Study Committee|ref=harv}}</ref>
On March 21, 2009, the bill died in committee when the legislature adjourned.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/03/antievolution-bill-dead-new-mexico-004691 |title=Antievolution bill dead in New Mexico |publisher=[[National Center for Science Education]] |date=March 23, 2009 |accessdate=2012-06-23|ref=harv}}</ref>
==Linkage with ''Expelled'' film== [[File:Bensteinatucsb.jpg|right|thumb|[[Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed|''Expelled'']] presenter [[Ben Stein]], who stated "Love of God and compassion and empathy leads you to a very glorious place. Science leads you to killing people."<ref name=miller>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2008/05/08/trouble_ahead_for_science/|title=Trouble ahead for science|first=Kenneth R. |last=Miller|authorlink=Kenneth R. Miller|date=May 8, 2008 |publisher=The [[Boston Globe]]|accessdate=2008-05-08|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080510070225/http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2008/05/08/trouble_ahead_for_science/|archivedate=May 10, 2008 |ref=harv}}</ref>]] Pre-release screenings for legislators of the controversial film ''[[Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed]]'', which portrays proponents of intelligent design as being "persecuted", have been presented by actor [[Ben Stein]].{{sfn|Simon|2008}} There were special showings for legislators from Florida and Missouri to promote Academic Freedom bills in those states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Intelligent design bill author wants debate|first=Chad|last=Livengood|date=April 5, 2008|publisher=Springfield News Leader| page=A.8|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/news_leader/access/1712285121.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+5%2C+2008&author=Chad+Livengood&pub=Springfield+News+Leader&edition=&startpage=A.8&desc=Intelligent+design+bill+author+wants+debate |ref=harv |accessdate=2014-04-27}}</ref>
The Florida showing was at the invitation of that Florida bill's House sponsor, Representative [[Alan Hays]], on March 12, 2008. It was a private screening restricted to legislators, their spouses, and their legislative aides. The press and public were excluded, and when the House general counsel was asked if that was legal under the Florida [[Freedom of information in the United States|sunshine law]] Hays said that it was technically legal as long as they just watched the film without discussing the issue or arranging any future votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-press.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080311/NEWS0120/80311045/1075 |title=Legislature invited to movie about creationism debate : news-press.com : The News-Press |accessdate=2008-03-13 |ref=harv }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Commenting on this, and the controversy over Roger Moore of the ''Orlando Sentinel'' previously managing to view the film against the wishes of the film company, House Democratic leader [[Dan Gelber]] of [[Miami Beach]] said, "It's kind of an irony: The public is expelled from a movie called Expelled."<ref name="03/10/2008MiamiHerald"/> The screening was attended by about 100 people, but few were legislators,<ref name=lawm>{{cite web |url=http://www.tallahassee.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080313/CAPITOLNEWS/803130323/1067/RSS15 |title=Lawmakers attend Tallahassee screening of movie by Ben Stein |publisher= Tallahassee Democrat |accessdate=2008-03-14 |ref=harv|year=2008}}</ref> and the majority of legislators stayed away.<ref name=eyes>{{cite web |url=http://www.tallahassee.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080314/OPINION01/803140322/1006/OPINION |title=Eyes wide open |publisher=Tallahassee Democrat |accessdate=2008-03-14 |ref=harv|year=2008}}</ref>
Shortly before the film was released on April 18, 2008, the producer of the film, Walt Ruloff, held a press conference on April 15 at the [[Heritage Foundation]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]. Ruloff announced his plans to use the ''Expelled'' film as part of a campaign to pass academic freedom bills in a variety of American states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/news/show/125988.html|title=Flunk this Movie!|first=Ronald|last=Bailey|date=April 16, 2008|publisher=Reason magazine|accessdate=2010-06-13|ref=harv|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090903075216/http://www.reason.com/news/show/125988.html|archivedate=September 3, 2009 }}</ref>
==Florida bills== <!--[[File:RondaStorms.jpg|left|thumb|[[Ronda Storms]] sponsored the bill in the [[Florida Senate]].]] --> On 29 February 2008, Senator [[Ronda Storms]] introduced an Academic Freedom bill (SB2692) in the [[Florida Senate]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.tbo.com/content/2008/mar/03/storms-evolution-bill-lets-teachers-contradict-the/ |title=Storms' Evolution Bill Lets Teachers Contradict Theory |first=Keith |last=Morelli |date=March 3, 2008 |work=[[The Tampa Tribune]] |accessdate=2010-06-13 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202130903/http://www2.tbo.com/content/2008/mar/03/storms-evolution-bill-lets-teachers-contradict-the/ |archivedate=December 2, 2008 }}</ref> which closely resembled both the Discovery Institute model statute and the previous Alabama bills.<ref name=NCSE_Flr1/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pandasthumb.org/archives/2008/03/antievolution-l.html|title=Anti-Evolution Legislation Introduced in Florida|first=Mike|last=Dunford|date=March 2, 2008|publisher=[[Panda's Thumb (blog)|Panda's Thumb]]|format=blog|accessdate=2010-06-13|ref=harv}}</ref> Its sponsor in the [[Florida House of Representatives]] (as HB1483) was Representative [[Alan Hays]], who claimed that the bill was simply drafted to allow teachers and students to discuss "the full range" of problems and ideas surrounding Darwin's theory without fear of punishment.<ref name="03/10/2008MiamiHerald"/> Hays and Storms were unable to name any teachers in Florida who have been disciplined for being critical of evolution in the science classroom. Hays said, "I want a balanced policy. I want students taught how to think, not what to think. There are problems with evolution. Have you ever seen a half-monkey, half human?"<ref name="03/10/2008MiamiHerald">{{cite web|title=Ben Stein weighs in on evolution fight |first=Marc |last=Caputo|date=March 10, 2008|publisher=[[Miami Herald]] |url=http://www.alliancealert.org/2008/03/11/florida-ben-stein-weighs-in-on-evolution-fight/ |accessdate=2014-04-27|ref=harv}}</ref> DI attorney Casey Luskin's statement at a press conference supporting the bill that, in his personal opinion, Intelligent Design constitutes "scientific information" (which the bill explicitly permits) was taken by the [[Miami Herald]] as an admission that "Intelligent Design could more easily be brought up in public-school science classrooms" under the proposed law.<ref name="03/15/2008MiamiHerald">{{cite web|title=Intelligent Design could slip into science class|first=Marc |last=Caputo|date=March 13, 2008|publisher=[[Miami Herald]]|url=http://www.nebscience.org/fla60.html |ref=harv |accessdate=2014-04-27}}</ref> The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] also expressed concerns that these bills might make it easier to teach intelligent design as science in public schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclufl.org/news_events/?action=viewRelease&emailAlertID=3384|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201053157/http://www.aclufl.org/news_events/?action=viewRelease&emailAlertID=3384|dead-url=yes|archive-date=December 1, 2010|title=Intelligent Design Should Not Be Taught in Florida's Public School Science Classrooms|first=Brandon |last=Hensler|date=March 12, 2008|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|format=Press release|accessdate=2010-06-13|ref=harv}}</ref> The bills were also opposed by [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry Nobel Prize]]-winner [[Harold Kroto]] who said, "it's an abuse of position not to teach science correctly to children".<ref name=Kroto>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20080415/NEWS/804150543/-1/newssitemap|title=Evolution fray attracts top scientist|first=Anna |last=Scott|date=April 15, 2008|publisher=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]|accessdate=2010-06-13|ref=harv}}</ref>
The Senate bill was later amended to define "scientific information" as "germane current facts, data, and peer-reviewed research specific to the topic of chemical and biological evolution as prescribed in Florida's Science Standards."<ref>{{cite web|title=Evolution criticism bill weakened|first=Marc |last=Caputo|date=March 26, 2008|publisher=[[Miami Herald]]|url=http://pd.miami.com/sp?aff=1100&keywords=Evolution+criticism+bill+weakened&submit.x=0&submit.y=0 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824044103/http://pd.miami.com/sp?aff=1100&keywords=Evolution+criticism+bill+weakened&submit.x=0&submit.y=0 |archive-date=August 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2010-06-13|ref=harv}}</ref> Storms refused to answer repeated direct questions from senate Democrats as to whether teachers would be permitted to teach Intelligent design under her bill and whether she believes that intelligent design meets its criteria for 'scientific information'.<ref name=sexed>{{cite news |title='Academic freedom' for evolution, not sex-ed|first=Marc|last=Caputo|work=[[Miami Herald]]|ref=harv}}</ref> The bill has also been criticized for its inconsistency in only protecting the freedom of teachers to discuss anti-evolution arguments, but not other controversies (such as birth control and abortion),<ref>{{cite web|title=Proposed Academic Freedom Act rife with mumbo jumbo|last=Mayo|first=Michael|date=March 20, 2008|publisher=[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]] |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sun_sentinel/access/1448805641.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+20%2C+2008&author=MICHAEL+MAYO+COMMENTARY&pub=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&edition=&startpage=B.1&desc=PROPOSED+ACADEMIC+FREEDOM+ACT+RIFE+WITH+MUMBO+JUMBO |ref=harv |accessdate=2014-04-27}}</ref> but when Democrats introduced a proposal to have the bill's protection extended to sex-education Storms had it voted down.<ref name=sexed/> The House bill underwent substantial modification and, as amended, requires "[[Critical Analysis of Evolution]]" to be taught. An attempt by Senator Storms to ease the bill's passage by substituting the heavily amended House version failed to win acceptance in the Senate, leaving two incompatible bills,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/04/antievolution-bills-continue-to-advance-florida-legislature-00158|title=Antievolution bills continue to advance through Florida legislature|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=April 29, 2008|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-17|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100627020509/http://ncse.com/news/2008/04/antievolution-bills-continue-to-advance-florida-legislature-00158|archivedate= 27 June 2010|ref=harv }}</ref> which died with the end of the legislative session on May 2.<ref>{{cite news|title=Evolution bills die in Legislature as session ends|first=Bill |last=Kaczor|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/775/story/519030.html|publisher=[[Miami Herald]]|date=May 2, 2008|accessdate=2010-06-17|ref=harv}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Louisiana act== A bill (SB561) named the "Louisiana Academic Freedom Act," was pre-filed on March 21, 2008, in the [[Louisiana Senate]] by the Education Committee chair, [[Ben Nevers]], a [[Bogalusa, Louisiana|Bogalusa]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]. While its name is the same as the Florida, Alabama and Discovery Institute bills, the Louisiana version is modeled on a policy adopted in 2006 by the [[Ouachita Parish]] School Board with the backing of the pro-creationism [[Louisiana Family Forum]] (LFF). The bill contends that "the teaching of some scientific subjects, such as biological evolution, the chemical origins of life, global warming, and human cloning, can cause controversy, and that some teachers may be unsure of the expectations concerning how they should present information on such subjects," and extends permission to Louisiana's teachers to "help students understand, analyze, critique, and review in an objective manner the scientific strengths and scientific weaknesses of existing scientific theories pertinent to the course being taught."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/03/antievolution-legislation-louisian-001431|title= Antievolution legislation in Louisiana|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=March 24, 2008|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-17|ref=harv}}</ref>
Nevers states that he was asked to sponsor the bill by the LFF. Gene Mills, executive director of the Louisiana Family Forum, stated that a bill is needed that makes it easier for teachers to delve into criticism of Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.<ref name=Advocate>{{cite news |title=Author denies bill lets creationism slip into schools |first=Will |last=Sentell |url=http://www.2theadvocate.com/news/17179166.html|newspaper=[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|The Advocate]]|date=April 1, 2008|accessdate=2010-06-17|ref=harv}}</ref> However in introducing the LFF-suggested bill he also stated that the LFF "believe that scientific data related to creationism should be discussed when dealing with Darwin's theory."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bill allows teaching creationism as science|first=Sylvia|last=Schon|url=http://www.hammondstar.com/articles/2008/04/06/top_stories/9327.txt|newspaper=Hammond Star|date=April 6, 2008|accessdate=2010-06-17|ref=harv|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419040815/http://www.hammondstar.com/articles/2008/04/06/top_stories/9327.txt|archive-date=April 19, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Barry W. Lynn]], executive director of [[Americans United for Separation of Church and State]] described the bill as "all about God in biology class".<ref name=Advocate/>
On April 21, 2008, Representative Frank Hoffman, who was the assistant superintendent of the Ouachita Parish school system at the time it adopted the LFF-backed policy, introduced an identical bill into the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] (HB1168).<ref name=1168backgrounder>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasciencecoalition.org/docs/Forrest_UpdatedAnalysis_SB_733_6.5.08.pdf |title=Analysis of SB 733, "LA Science Education Act" |first=Barbara |last=Forrest |authorlink=Barbara Forrest |date=April 27, 2008 |publisher=self published |accessdate=2010-06-18 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828011551/http://www.lasciencecoalition.org/docs/Forrest_UpdatedAnalysis_SB_733_6.5.08.pdf |archivedate=August 28, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.la.us/billdata/History.asp?sessionid=08RS&billid=HB1168|title=HB1168 Bill history|year=2008|publisher=Louisiana State Legislature|accessdate=2010-06-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208021900/http://www.legis.state.la.us/billdata/History.asp?sessionid=08RS&billid=SB561|archivedate=8 February 2012|ref=harv}}</ref> The next day, references to evolution, global warming and other subjects were stripped from the senate bill and replaced with calls for more general changes in science classes,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.2theadvocate.com/news/17949069.html|title=Evolution talk cut from bill|first=Will |last=Sentell|date=April 20, 2008|publisher=[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|The Advocate]]|accessdate=2010-06-18|ref=harv}}</ref> and it was renamed the "[[Louisiana Science Education Act]]" (and renumbered SB733),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.2theadvocate.com/opinion/17931559.html|title=Our Views: Just another waste of time|last= staff|date=April 19, 2008|publisher=[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|The Advocate]]|accessdate=2010-06-18|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.la.us/billdata/History.asp?sessionid=08RS&billid=SB561 |title=SB561 Bill history |publisher=Louisiana State Legislature |year=2008 |format=primary source |accessdate=2010-06-18 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208021900/http://www.legis.state.la.us/billdata/History.asp?sessionid=08RS&billid=SB561 |archivedate=2012-02-08 |df= }}</ref> and was passed unanimously on April 28, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/04/louisiana-antievolution-bill-passes-senate-001435|title=Louisiana antievolution bill passes Senate|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=April 29, 2008|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-06-28|ref=harv}}</ref> On June 11, 2008, the House bill was passed by a vote of 94-3. In response, Americans United noted that Louisiana legislators have repeatedly tried to water down the teaching of evolution, with previous attempts having been deemed unconstitutional by the [[Supreme Court of the United States]], and suggest that this legislation "opens the door to teaching creationism in public schools, an action that is likely to spark litigation".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.org/media/press-releases/archives/2008/06/louisiana-will-f.html|title=Louisiana Will Face Lawsuit If New Law Brings Religion Into Public School Science Classes, Says Americans United|author=[[Americans United for Separation of Church and State]]|date=June 11, 2008|accessdate=2010-06-28|ref=harv|format=press release|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100629131327/http://www.au.org/media/press-releases/archives/2008/06/louisiana-will-f.html|archivedate= June 29, 2010 }}</ref>
On June 12, 2008, the day after the House bill passed, "concerned parents, teachers and scientists" formed Louisiana Coalition for Science, "[i]n response to numerous attacks on science education in the Bayou State". Founding members include prominent philosopher and critic of the [[intelligent design movement]] [[Barbara Forrest]] and veteran biology teacher Patsye Peebles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lasciencecoalition.org/2008/06/12/reject_sb_733/ |title=Press Release: Reject SB 733 |author=Louisiana Coalition for Science |date=June 12, 2008 |accessdate=2010-06-28 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810022627/http://lasciencecoalition.org/2008/06/12/reject_sb_733/ |archivedate=August 10, 2010 }}</ref>
In late June 2008, Louisiana governor [[Bobby Jindal]] signed the bill into law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/news/index.ssf/2008/06/science_law_could_set_tone_for.html|title=Science law could set tone for Jindal|first= Bill|last= Barrow|date=June 26, 2008|publisher=The Times-Picayune|location= New Orleans Metro Real Time News|accessdate=2010-06-29|ref=harv|archiveurl= http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20100529165457/http%3A//www%2Enola%2Ecom/news/index%2Essf/2008/06/science_law_could_set_tone_for%2Ehtml|archivedate= 29 May 2010}}</ref>
The legislation has been criticized by the [[American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asbmb.org/uploadedFiles/ASBMBToday/Content/Archive/ASBMBToday-August-2008.pdf|title=''President's Message'': It Is Alive|first=Gregory A. |last=Petsko|date=July 9, 2008|publisher=American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology|accessdate=2010-06-28|ref=harvformat=press release}}</ref> and the [[Society of Vertebrate Paleontology]], with the latter calling for its repeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vertpaleo.org/news/permalinks/2008/09/04/PRESS%2DRELEASE%2D%2D%2DPaleontology%2Dsociety%2Durges%2Drepeal%2Dof%2DLouisiana%2DScience%2DEducation%2DAct/ |title=Paleontology society urges repeal of Louisiana Science Education Act |first=Mark |last=Terry |date=September 4, 2008 |publisher=[[Society of Vertebrate Paleontology]] |accessdate=2010-06-30 |ref=harv |format=press release |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726044340/http://www.vertpaleo.org/news/permalinks/2008/09/04/PRESS-RELEASE---Paleontology-society-urges-repeal-of-Louisiana-Science-Education-Act/ |archivedate=July 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
Conservative commentator [[John Derbyshire]] questioned the constitutionality of the law, and its likely effects: {{quote|Some local school board will take the Act as a permit to bring religious instruction into their science classes. That will irk some parents. Those parents will sue. There will be a noisy and expensive federal lawsuit, possibly followed by further noisy and expensive appeals. The school board will inevitably lose. The property owners of that school district will take the financial hit.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://corner.nationalreview.com/post/?q=NGI0ZmZlMDVlMDM0MzVhNTcwNzA3MmYwYjY2NGM0Y2Q |title=Patsy Jindal |last=Derbyshire |first=John |authorlink=John Derbyshire |work=[[National Review]] Online |date=July 9, 2008 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207031517/http://corner.nationalreview.com/post/?q=NGI0ZmZlMDVlMDM0MzVhNTcwNzA3MmYwYjY2NGM0Y2Q |archivedate=February 7, 2009 |df= }}</ref>}}
In a December 2008 ''[[Scientific American]]'' article [[Glenn Branch]] and [[Eugenie Scott]] stated:
{{quote|In the meantime, it is clear why the Louisiana Science Education Act is pernicious: it tacitly encourages teachers and local school districts to mis-educate students about evolution, whether by teaching creationism as a scientifically credible alternative or merely by misrepresenting evolution as scientifically controversial. Vast areas of evolutionary science are for all intents and purposes scientifically settled; textbooks and curricula used in the public schools present precisely such basic, uncomplicated, uncontroversial material. Telling students that evolution is a theory in crisis is—to be blunt—a lie.<ref name=sciam>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=the-latest-face-of-creationism |title=The Latest Face of Creationism in the Classroom|first= Glenn |last=Branch |first2= Eugenie C. |last2=Scott|journal= [[Scientific American]]|date=December 2008|ref=harv}}</ref>}}
== Missouri bills == On April 1, 2008, representative Robert Wayne Cooper introduced a bill to add a "new section [into state law] relating to teacher academic freedom to teach scientific evidence regarding evolution" into the [[Missouri House of Representatives]] (HB2554). It would require educational authorities to "endeavor to create an environment within public elementary and secondary schools that encourages students to explore scientific questions, learn about scientific evidence, develop critical thinking skills, and respond appropriately and respectfully to differences of opinion about controversial issues, including such subjects as the teaching of biological and chemical evolution" and forbid them from "prohibit[ing] any teacher in a public school system of this state from helping students understand, analyze, critique, and review in an objective manner the scientific strengths and scientific weaknesses of theories of biological or chemical evolution." Previously in 2004, Cooper had introduced two unsuccessful bills (HB 911 and HB 1722) that called for equal time for [[intelligent design]] in Missouri schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.house.mo.gov/billtracking/bills081/biltxt/intro/HB2554I.htm|title= House bill no. 2554|first=Robert Wayne|last=Cooper|date=April 1, 2008|publisher=[[Missouri House of Representatives]]|format=primary source|accessdate=2010-07-03|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/04/new-antievolution-bill-missouri-001671|title=A new antievolution bill in Missouri|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=April 4, 2008|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-07-03|ref=harv}}</ref>
The bill was passed by the House Committee on Elementary and Secondary Education on April 30, 2008, but died when the Missouri legislative session ended on May 16, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/05/missouri-antievolution-bill-dies-001670 |title=Missouri antievolution bill dies |date=May 19, 2008 |author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2008-05-20|ref=harv}}</ref>
On February 10, 2009, Representative Robert Wayne Cooper introduced a bill (HB 656) to add a "new section relating to teacher academic freedom to teach scientific evidence regarding evolution" to existing legislation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/02/antievolution-legislation-missouri-004615|title=Antievolution legislation in Missouri|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=February 17, 2009|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-07-03|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.house.mo.gov/billtracking/bills091/biltxt/intro/HB0656I.htm|title= House Bill 656|first= Robert Wayne|last= Cooper|last2= Sutherland|last3= Emery|last4= Sanders|last5= Neives|last6= Cox|date=February 10, 2009|publisher= [[Missouri House of Representatives]]|format= primary source|accessdate=2010-07-03|ref=harv|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100528073915/http://www.house.mo.gov/billtracking/bills091/biltxt/intro/HB0656I.htm|archivedate= 28 May 2010 }}</ref> It died, without having been assigned to a committee, with the end of the legislative session on May 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/05/antievolution-bill-dead-missouri-004780|title=Antievolution bill dead in Missouri|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=May 15, 2009|publisher=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-07-03|ref=harv}}</ref>
==Michigan bills== On April 30, 2008, a bill on "academic freedom to teach evidence regarding controversial scientific subjects" (HB 6027) was introduced in the [[Michigan House of Representatives]] by representative John Moolenaar.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(qxsz4t2tanscrpjju2rynojh))/mileg.aspx?page=GetObject&objectname=2008-HB-6027 |title=House Bill 6027|format=primary source|year= 2008|publisher= [[Michigan House of Representatives]]|ref=harv}}</ref> On June 3, 2008, an identical bill (SB 1361) was introduced into the [[Michigan Senate]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2006/01/second-antievolution-bill-michigan-00833|title=A second antievolution bill in Michigan|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=January 30, 2006|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-07-08|ref=harv}}</ref> Both bills later died in committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ncse.com/news/2008/12/antievolution-bills-dead-michigan-003397|title=Antievolution bills dead in Michigan|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=December 19, 2008|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2018-01-09|ref=harv}}</ref>
==South Carolina bill== A bill (SB 1386) was introduced in the [[South Carolina Senate]] on May 15, 2008 by Senator [[Michael L. Fair]] to amend the state's education code to provide:<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.scstatehouse.net/sess117_2007-2008/bills/1386.htm|title=SB 1386|publisher=[[South Carolina Senate]]|format=primary source|ref=harv|year=2008|access-date=May 8, 2013|archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080717191058/http://www.scstatehouse.net/sess117_2007-2008/bills/1386.htm|archive-date=July 17, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> {{quote|The State Board of Education, superintendents of public school districts, and public school administrators may not prohibit a teacher in a public school of this State from helping his students understand, analyze, critique, and review the scientific strengths and weaknesses of biological and chemical evolution in an objective manner. This act does not condone the promotion of religious or nonreligious doctrine, the promotion of discrimination for or against a particular set of religious beliefs or nonreligious beliefs, or the promotion of discrimination for or against religion or nonreligion. By no later than September 1, 2008, the State Department of Education shall notify district superintendents of the provisions of this act, and each superintendent shall then disseminate to all employees within his district a copy of the provisions of this act.}}
The [[National Center for Science Education]] described the bill as "aimed at undermining the teaching of evolution".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2008/05/antievolution-legislation-south-carolina-001680 |title=Antievolution legislation in South Carolina|author= [[National Center for Science Education]]|format=self published newsletter|ref=harv|year=2008}}</ref>
Jim Foster, a spokesman for the state Department of Education, disputed the need for the bill:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.greenvilleonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080516/NEWS01/805160318/1001/NEWS01 |title=Greenville Sen. Mike Fair seeks to open debate on teaching of evolution |first=Tim |last=Smith |newspaper=Greenville Online |date=May 16, 2008 |ref=harv }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> {{quote|Science teachers are already free to discuss science. So unless the intent is to introduce content that's not scientific, it's difficult to see why we need this.}}
The bill died in committee when the South Carolina legislature adjourned on June 5, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ncse.com/news/2008/06/antievolution-legislation-south-carolina-dies-001677|title=Antievolution legislation in South Carolina dies|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=March 18, 2005|accessdate=2010-07-08|ref=harv}}</ref>
==Iowa bill== On February 3, 2009, a bill for an "Evolution Academic Freedom Act" was introduced into the [[Iowa Senate]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://coolice.legis.state.ia.us/Cool-ICE/default.asp?Category=billinfo&Service=Billbook&ga=83&hbill=HF183 |title= House File 183 |first=Rod |last=Roberts |last2=Carroll |date=February 3, 2009 |publisher=[[Iowa Legislature]] |format= primary source |accessdate=2010-07-13 |ref=harv }}</ref> by State Representative [[Rod Roberts]], R-Carroll. More than 200 faculty members at 20 Iowa colleges signed a statement opposing a proposed state law:
{{quote|It is misleading to claim that there is any controversy or dissent within the vast majority of the scientific community regarding the scientific validity of evolutionary theory ... 'academic freedom' for alternative theories is simply a mechanism to introduce religious or nonscientific doctrines into our science curriculum.<ref name="press-citizen">{{cite news |title=Evolution bill raises ire of UI professors |first=Brian |last=Morelli |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/press_citizen/access/1689049111.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+27%2C+2009&author=Brian+Morelli&pub=Press+-+Citizen&edition=&startpage=A.3&desc=Evolution+bill+raises+ire+of+UI+professors |newspaper=Press-Citizen |location=Iowa City, Iowa |date=February 27, 2009 |page=A.3 |accessdate=2010-07-10 |ref=harv }}{{subscription}}</ref>}}
Glenn Branch of the National Center for Science Education said that the Iowa statement represented the first organized effort by college faculty members throughout a state to oppose this creationist strategy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Iowa-Professors-Mobilize-Ag/1549/|title= Iowa Professors Mobilize Against Measure on Teaching Alternatives to Evolution|first= Peter |last=Schmidt|date=February 25, 2009|publisher=[[Chronicle of Higher Education]]|accessdate=2010-07-10|ref=harv}}{{subscription}}</ref> It died in committee on March 13, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/03/antievolution-bill-dead-iowa-004653|title=Antievolution bill dead in Iowa|author=[[National Center for Science Education]]|date=March 16, 2009|format=self published newsletter|accessdate=2010-07-08|ref=harv}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Academic Bill of Rights]] *[[Critical Analysis of Evolution]] *[[Discovery Institute intelligent design campaigns]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}} * {{cite book |last = Foerstel |first = Herbert |title = Toxic MIX? |publisher = Greenwood |location = Westport |year = 2009 |isbn = 0-313-36234-3 |page = 163| ref = harv }} * {{cite news |url = http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2005/05/30/050530fa_fact |title = Devolution: Why intelligent design isn't |last = Orr |first = H. Allen |publisher = The New Yorker |date = May 30, 2005 |ref = harv }} * {{cite news | url=https://www.motherjones.com/blue-marble/2012/03/law-repeal-creationism-classrooms-louisiana-science-education-act |title=New Bill Aims to Repeal Louisiana's Anti-Evolution Law |last=Pasulka |first=Nicole |publisher=Mother Jones |date=March 10, 2012 |ref=harv }} * {{cite web |url=http://pewforum.org/Science-and-Bioethics/The-Biology-Wars-The-Religion-Science-and-Education-Controversy.aspx |first=Michael |last=Cromartie|title=The Biology Wars: The Religion, Science and Education Controversy |date=December 5, 2005 |publisher=The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life |accessdate=2010-06-08 |quote= |ref=harv |type=primary source|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100610082926/http://pewforum.org/Science-and-Bioethics/The-Biology-Wars-The-Religion-Science-and-Education-Controversy.aspx|archivedate= 10 June 2010}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.academicfreedompetition.com/freedom.php|title=Model Academic Freedom Statue on Evolution|author=Discovery Institute|year= 2007|ref=harv |accessdate=2012-07-20}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/filesDB-download.php?command=download&id=113 |author=House of Representatives|title=Conference Report to accompany H.R. 1, No Child Left Behind Act of 2001|type=primary source|ref=harv|date = December 13, 2001}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.discovery.org/a/1172 |title=Santorum Language on Evolution |first=Rick |last=Santorum |authorlink=Rick Santorum |date=January 31, 2002 |publisher=Center for Science and Culture |accessdate=2010-06-08 |ref=harv |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100427135824/http://www.discovery.org/a/1172|archivedate= 27 April 2010}} * {{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120967537476060561 |title=Evolution's Critics Shift Tactics With Schools |first=Stephanie |last=Simon |date=May 2, 2008 |publisher=Wall Street Journal |ref=harv |accessdate=2012-08-12}}{{subscription}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.flsenate.gov/data/session/2008/Senate/bills/analysis/pdf/2008s2692.ed.pdf |title=Bill Analysis and Fiscal Impact Statement |author=The Professional Staff of the Education Pre-K-12 Committee |type=primary source|date=March 26, 2008 |publisher=[[Florida Senate]]|ref=harv |accessdate=2010-06-07 }} * {{cite web |title=Congressional Record: Proceedings of the 107th Congress, first Session {{ndash}} Senate |url=http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/filesDB-download.php?command=download&id=111 |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-06-07 |series=82 |volume=147 |date=June 13, 2001 |publisher=U.S. Congress |author=U.S. Congress |location= Washington, DC |type=primary source |ref=harv |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100427151442/http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/filesDB-download.php?command=download&id=111 |archivedate= 27 April 2010 }}

revision.text:
'''Apple Certified System Administrator''' (ACSA) was an [[Apple Inc.]] designed [[Apple certification programs|certification program]] to verify an in-depth knowledge of Apple technical architecture. The last ACSA certification was offered for [[Mac OS X v10.6]] and will not be available for [[Mac OS X v10.7]] and later.
An ACSA will have demonstrated the ability to install and configure Mac OS X systems, as well as the ability to design and configure networks; enable, customize, tune, and troubleshoot a wide range of services; and integrate [[Mac OS X]], [[Mac OS X Server]], and other Apple technologies within a multi-platform networked environment.
The ACSA for [[Mac OS X v10.6]] was phased out in June 2012 and it will not be returning for [[Mac OS X v10.7]] and later. The [[Apple Certified Technical Coordinator]] v10.7 now replaced the ACSA as Apple's highest certification for systems administrators. Prior to its phase out, it was available for [[Mac OS X v.10.6]] and [[Mac OS X v10.5]]. The [[Mac OS X v10.4]] exam was phased out in October 2009, and the [[Mac OS X v10.3]] exam was phased out in December 2005.
For Mac OS X v.10.6 Snow Leopard, the Mac OS X Advanced System Administration exam was eliminated, and replaced with Security & Mobility. The following exams were required: *Mac OS X Server Essentials v10.6 Exam *Mac OS X Directory Services v10.6 Exam *Mac OS X Deployment v10.6 Exam *Mac OS X Security and Mobility v10.6 Exam
For Mac OS X v10.5 Leopard, the ACSA program was revised to require much more knowledge of the Mac OS X Server than 10.4. To achieve the ACSA 10.5, the following exams were required: *Mac OS X Server Essentials v10.5 Exam *Mac OS X Directory Services v10.5 Exam *Mac OS X Deployment v10.5 Exam *Mac OS X Advanced System Admin v10.5 Exam
To achieve the ACSA for Mac OS X v.10.4 Tiger, new candidates took any of the following exams to earn the seven required certification credits: *Mac OS X Deployment v10.4 Exam (9L0-609) -- 2 credits *Xsan Administration v1.1 Exam (9L0-610) -- 3 credits *Directory Services Integration and Administration v10.4 Exam (9L0-611) -- 4 credits *Security Best Practices v10.4 Exam (9L0-612) -- 3 credits *Podcasting and Streaming Internet Media Exam (9L0-613) -- 3 credits *Command Line Setup and Administration v10.4 Exam (9L0-614) -- 3 credits *Network Account Management v10.4 Exam (9L0-615) -- 3 credits *Xsan for Pro Video Technician v10.4 Exam (9L0-932) -- 3 credits
To move on to the [[Apple Certified Trainer]] passing the test is only one step. Trainer candidates must not only take the Apple Training course, they must also pass the exam with a 90% or better, and attend a train-the-trainer class.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100522005833/http://training.apple.com/certification/macosx Apple Certifications]
{{Apple}}
[[Category:Apple Inc. services]] [[Category:Information technology qualifications]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Arthur William Oldham''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (6 September 1926 – 4 May 2003) was an English composer and choirmaster. He founded the [[Edinburgh Festival]] Chorus in 1965, the Chorus of the [[Orchestre de Paris]] in 1975, and the [[Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra|Concertgebouw Orchestra]] Chorus in Amsterdam in 1979.<ref name=indy/> He also worked with the [[Scottish Opera]] Chorus 1966–74 and directed the [[London Symphony Chorus]] 1969–76.<ref name=guard>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/may/14/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries|title=Obituary: Arthur Oldham|work=the Guardian|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> For his work with the LSO Chorus, he won three [[Grammy Award]]s. He was also a composer, mainly of religious works, but also a ballet and an opera.<ref name=indy/>
==Biography== Arthur Oldham was born in London in 1926. When he was age 14, his mother committed suicide by gassing herself in an oven,<ref name=indy/> and he was brought up in [[Wallington, London|Wallington]], at that time in [[Surrey]].<ref name=jstor>[https://www.jstor.org/pss/954346 Conrad Wilson, Arthur Oldham, jstor]</ref><ref name=durrant/> He won a scholarship to the [[Royal College of Music]], where he studied composition under [[Herbert Howells]]. He then became [[Benjamin Britten]]'s only private pupil<ref name=guard/><ref name=herald>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/arthur-oldham-composer-teacher-and-founder-of-the-edinburgh-festival-chorus-who-was-renowned-here-and-abroad-1.119247|title=Arthur Oldham Composer, teacher, and founder of the Edinburgh Festival Chorus who was renowned here and abroad|work=Herald Scotland|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> at [[Aldeburgh]] between 1945 and 1951.<ref name=nmc>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmcrec.co.uk/composer/oldham-arthur|title=Oldham, Arthur - NMC Recordings|work=nmcrec.co.uk|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> (He claims that the bar lines on the manuscript of ''[[Peter Grimes]]'' were his work.<ref name=durrant>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/edinburgh-festival-the-master-of-chorus-masters-the-man-at-the-back--arthur-oldham-for-30-years-master-of-the-edinburgh-festival-chorus--is-bowing-out-sabine-durrant-talked-to-him-before-his-final-performances-1385875.html|title=Edinburgh Festival: The master of chorus masters: The man at the back - Arthur Oldham, for 30 years master of the Edinburgh Festival Chorus - is bowing out. Sabine Durrant talked to him before his final performances|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>) He and Britten came into conflict over their ideas about choral music, but they later worked together in Edinburgh on Britten's ''Voices for Today'', Op. 75, and the ''[[War Requiem]]''.<ref name=indy/> Until 1968 the only published vocal score of Britten's ''[[The Little Sweep]]'' was the piano duet and percussion version prepared by Arthur Oldham.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brittenpears.org/?page=research/catalogue/detail.html&id=221|title=Britten-Pears Foundation - Home|work=brittenpears.org|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
He was appointed musical director of the [[Rambert Dance Company|Ballet Rambert]] in 1945, aged only 19. His music first came to public notice in 1946, when his ballet ''Mr Punch'' was performed by the Ballet Rambert at [[Sadler's Wells Theatre|Sadler's Wells]], and was included in the Rambert's 1947–48 tour of Australia and New Zealand.<ref name=indy/> Several of his own pieces were heard at early Aldeburgh Festivals.<ref name=nmc/> He also composed for the [[The Royal Ballet|Royal Ballet]] for a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballet-dance.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=16578&sid=05b193958fc398c78e5f9594fb98d602|title=CriticalDance Forum • View topic - Arthur Oldham Obituary|work=ballet-dance.com|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
He arranged Britten's ''[[Variations on a Theme of Frank Bridge]]'' (a work for string orchestra) for full orchestra, for the ballet ''Le Rêve de Léonor'', choreographed by [[Frederick Ashton]]. This had its first performance on 26 April 1949 at the Prince's Theatre, London, by the Ballet de Paris de [[Roland Petit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a6xcZf0Vt5cC&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=britten+leonor&source=bl&ots=SzY5RPqL2X&sig=_tdaK-3YI_0289YvrKE-iLx_7as&hl=en&ei=VkDBS_29MYrg7AOA9NDrCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=britten%20leonor&f=false|title=Benjamin Britten|work=google.com.au|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>
In 1952, after [[Edmund Rubbra]] pulled out of the project, Oldham provided a variation for ''[[Variations on an Elizabethan Theme]]'', a [[Classical music written in collaboration|collaborative work]] with other contributions by [[Lennox Berkeley]], Britten, [[Imogen Holst]], [[Humphrey Searle]], [[Michael Tippett]] and [[William Walton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Themes-Variations-Various/dp/B00005A7LD|title=Themes and Variations by BBC Symphony Orchestra, None: Amazon.co.uk: Music|work=amazon.co.uk|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AMyKjyzEW_kC&pg=PA106&lpg=PA106&dq=guirlande+Campra&source=bl&ots=PiQh66hgNV&sig=4UnEnJm5NbPSJLfo4NbaOKRTB7k&hl=en&ei=PfG_S43fGI3-7AOzzPDACQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CA0Q6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=guirlande%20Campra&f=false|title=Letters from a Life: 1952-1957|work=google.com.au|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> That year, his modern treatment of [[Thomas Arne]]'s pastiche opera ''[[Love in a Village]]'' was staged by the [[English Opera Group]]. Criticism of the work led to a nervous breakdown and his working outside music for some time.<ref name=guard/>
He then became a [[Roman Catholic]] and was employed as a teacher at [[Scotus Academy]] and choirmaster at [[St Mary's Cathedral, Edinburgh (Roman Catholic)|St Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral]], Edinburgh.<ref name=jstor/> He introduced Scottish pre-Reformation music such as [[Robert Carver (composer)|Robert Carver]]'s 19-part motet ''O Bone Jesu''. Britten's ''[[Missa Brevis (Britten)|Missa Brevis]]'' had its first performance in Scotland under Oldham's direction.<ref name=stm/> His work at the Cathedral was noticed by people such as [[Carlo Maria Giulini]] and [[Georg Solti]].<ref name=guard/><ref name=herald/>
The first performance in Scotland (and one of the earliest in the United Kingdom<ref name=indy/>) of [[Gustav Mahler|Mahler]]'s [[Symphony No. 8 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 8 "Symphony of a Thousand"]] was scheduled for the opening night of the 1965 [[Edinburgh Festival]], with the [[Royal Scottish National Orchestra|Scottish National Orchestra]], but a suitable choir was lacking. [[George Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood|Lord Harewood]] and [[Alexander Gibson (conductor)|Alexander Gibson]] approached Oldham to create one and train the singers, and the Edinburgh Festival Chorus was born.<ref name=guard/><ref name=herald/> Under his direction for the next 12 years, the chorus went on to participate in major works such as [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[Requiem (Verdi)|Requiem]]'' (under Giulini), [[Michael Tippett|Tippett]]'s ''[[A Child of Our Time]]'' (under Gibson), [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s ''[[Magnificat (Bach)|Magnificat]]'' (under [[Herbert von Karajan]]), [[Sergei Prokofiev|Prokofiev]]'s ''[[Seven, They are Seven]]'' (under [[Gennady Rozhdestvensky]]], Mahler's [[Symphony No. 2 (Mahler)|"Resurrection" Symphony]] (under [[Leonard Bernstein]]), [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]]'s ''[[A German Requiem (Brahms)|A German Requiem]]'' (under [[Daniel Barenboim]]), and [[Igor Stravinsky|Stravinsky]]'s ''[[Symphony of Psalms]]'' (under [[Claudio Abbado]]).<ref name=guard/> He was instrumental in the first Scottish performances of Britten's ''[[War Requiem]]'', under Alexander Gibson.<ref name=herald/> He also continued with the St Mary's Cathedral Choir until 1971.<ref name=stm/>
Davidson was the recipient of the 1973 [[St Mungo Prize]], awarded to the individual who has done most in the previous three years to improve and promote the city of Glasgow.<ref name='GlasStory'>{{cite web|title=AP Somervillen|url=http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image/?inum=TGSS00044|work=A P Somerville|publisher=The Glasgow Story|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>
He also worked with the [[London Symphony Chorus]] between 1969 and 1976, winning three [[Grammy Award]]s.
He left for Paris in 1977 to create the [[Orchestre de Paris]]'s Chorus at Daniel Barenboim's request.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/12/news/12iht-obits_ed3__2.html?pagewanted=1 New York Times, 12 May 2003]</ref> For his farewell appearance in Edinburgh he wrote ''Psalms in Time of War'', which was performed at the 1977 Edinburgh Festival.<ref name=indy/> His first project with the Paris chorus was [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s ''[[Te Deum (Berlioz)|Te Deum]]'', under Barenboim, for which he had auditioned 1,700 people to create a chorus of 200 singers.<ref name=indy/> From 1987 to 1994 he commuted weekly between Paris and Edinburgh, working with both choirs. In 1992, the Edinburgh Chorus presented [[Arnold Schoenberg|Schoenberg]]'s ''[[Moses und Aron]]''.<ref name=indy/><ref name=herald/> From 1994, he worked with the Orchestre de Paris Chorus exclusively. He celebrated 20 years with the chorus in 1996 with a new work, ''The Will of Villon''.<ref name=indy/> He retired from that chorus in 2002.<ref name=indy/>
Arthur Oldham died in [[Villejuif]] in 2003, aged 76.<ref name=indy>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/arthur-oldham-730288.html|title=Arthur Oldham|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> [[Gabriel Fauré|Fauré]]'s ''[[Requiem (Fauré)|Requiem]]'' was performed in his memory.<ref name=herald/> He was married twice, and left 2 sons and 2 daughters.<ref name=indy/>
The Arthur Oldham/Michael Lester-Cribb Memorial Fund has been created to honour the joint work of Oldham and Michael Lester-Cribb, the Edinburgh Festival Chorus's pianist.<ref>[http://www.nycos.co.uk/content/mediaassets/doc/Newsletter_2008.pdf National Youth Choir of Scotland]</ref>
==Grammy Awards== Arthur Oldham shared the credit for three [[Grammy Award]]s for his work with the [[London Symphony Chorus]]: * [[14th Grammy Awards]] (1972) – [[Grammy Award for Best Choral Performance|Best Choral Performance, Classical]] **[[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s ''[[Requiem (Berlioz)|Requiem]]'' ([[Colin Davis]], conductor; Oldham and Russell Burgess, choir directors) * [[16th Grammy Awards]] (1974) – [[Grammy Award for Best Choral Performance|Best Choral Performance, Classical (other than opera)]] **[[William Walton|Walton]]'s ''[[Belshazzar's Feast (Walton)|Belshazzar's Feast]]'' ([[André Previn]], conductor; Oldham, choirmaster) * [[19th Grammy Awards]] (1977) – [[Grammy Award for Best Choral Performance|Best Choral Performance (other than opera)]] **[[Sergei Rachmaninoff|Rachmaninoff]]'s ''[[The Bells (Rachmaninoff)|The Bells]]'' (Previn, conductor; Oldham, choirmaster)
==Works== This is an '''incomplete''' list of Arthur Oldham's compositions:
* ''Mr Punch'', ballet * arrangement of [[Thomas Arne]]'s opera pastiche ''[[Love in a Village]]'' * ''Psalms in Time of War'' * ''The Will of Villon'' * ''Blind Audlay's Carol'' (commissioned by the Purcell Singers for the Aldeburgh Festival)<ref name=jstor/> * ''The Land of Green Ginger'', a musical for children<ref name=jstor/> * A song cycle on poems by Alexander Montgomery (commissioned by [[Peter Pears]])<ref name=jstor/> * ''Hymns for the Amusement of Children''<ref>[http://www.oup.co.uk/hirecat/Oldham/ Oxford University Press] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606070710/http://www.oup.co.uk/hirecat/Oldham/ |date=6 June 2011 }}</ref> * ''Now's the Time for Mirth and Play'', unison voice.organ<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicroom.com/se/ID_No/0337989/details.html|title=Arthur Oldham: Now's The Time For Mirth And Play Unison/Organ|work=Musicroom|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * Two Hymn Tunes, SATB/organ<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicroom.com/se/ID_No/0337988/details.html|title=Arthur Oldham: Two Hymn Tunes Satb/Organ (1. Charity 2.Dunbar) - Satb/Organ Accompaniment Vocal Score - Sheet Music & Songbooks - Musicroom.com|work=Musicroom|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''Remember O thou man'', carol<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Christmas-Carols-at-Westminster-Abbey/dp/B000001GO9|title=Christmas Carols at Westminster Abbey|work=amazon.co.uk|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> (This has been recorded a number of times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arkivmusic.com/classical/albumList.jsp?name_id1=8904&name_role1=1&comp_id=44220&bcorder=15|title=Arthur Oldham|work=arkivmusic.com|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref>) * ''Three Chinese Lyrics'', song cycle<ref>[http://www.lieder.net/lieder/assemble_texts.html?SongCycleId=4785 The Lied and Art Song Texts Page]</ref> (recorded by [[Peter Pears]] and [[Benjamin Britten]]<ref>[http://recordings.online.fr/record.php?i=431&m=4])</ref> * ''Circus Parade''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faqs.org/copyright/circus-parade-thirteen-short-pieces-for-piano-grades-2-3-by/#id7610027|title=Circus parade. Thirteen short pieces for piano grades 2-3. By Arthur Frackenpohl|work=faqs.org|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''Angels from the Realms of Glory'' (arrangement)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faqs.org/copyright/angels-from-the-realms-of-glory-w-james-montgomery-m-henry/#id7125185|title=Angels from the realms of glory. w James Montgomery, m Henry Smart, editing & arr.: Walter Ehret|work=faqs.org|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''Hymn of dedication''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faqs.org/copyright/hymn-of-dedication-for-tenor-solo-and-satb-words-ronald/#id6281049|title=Hymn of dedication. For tenor solo and SATB. Words: Ronald Duncan, music: Arthur Oldham|work=faqs.org|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''I sing of a maiden''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faqs.org/copyright/i-sing-of-a-maiden-a-christmas-madrigal-for-4-part-chorus/#id8654540|title=I sing of a maiden; a Christmas madrigal. For 4-part chorus of women's voices, a capella (SSAA) or men's voices (TTBB) Musical setting: John David Kraehenbuehl|work=faqs.org|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''Saint Francis''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faqs.org/copyright/saint-francis-in-ecstasy-detail-upper-left-corner-no-12-by/#id7347600|title=Saint Francis in ecstasy, detail: upper left corner. No. 12. By Giovanni Bellini, renewable matter: The Frick Collection|work=faqs.org|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''Laudes Creaturarum'' (recorded by the St Mary's Cathedral Choir and the Scottish National Orchestra.<ref name=stm>{{cite web|url=http://www.stmaryscathedral.co.uk/choir.html|title=St Mary's RC Cathedral|work=stmaryscathedral.co.uk|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> * ''Missa Sancti Thomas More'', 4 (SATB) part mass setting
==References== {{reflist}}
