{{Infobox University |name = University of Kinshasa |native_name = Université de Kinshasa |image = Université de Kinshasa - Blason.svg |image_upright = 0.6 |caption = Logo of the University of Kinshasa |motto = ''Scientia Splendet et Conscientia''
[[Latin]]: "Science shines and so does conscience" |established = 1954 |faculty = 1,530{{cite web | url=http://www.sarua.org/?q=uni_Universit%C3%A9%20de%20Kinshasa | title =Université de Kinshasa | accessdate =December 15, 2010 | publisher =Southern African Regional Universities Association }} |rector = [[Ngoma ya Nzuzi Daniel]] (since 2015) |city= [[Kinshasa]] |country= [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] |campus= |students= 26,186 |postgrad= |colours= Red, Yellow and Blue |type = [[public university|Public]] }} The '''University of Kinshasa''' ({{lang-fr|Université de Kinshasa}}), commonly known as '''UNIKIN''', is one of the three major universities in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], together with the [[University of Kisangani]] and [[University of Lubumbashi]]. Originally founded in 1954 as [[Lovanium University]] during [[Belgian Congo|Belgian colonial rule]], the current university was established following the division of the [[National University of Zaire]] (UNAZA) in 1981. It is located in [[Kinshasa]]. The university had an enrollment of 26,186 and a faculty and research staff of 1,530 in the 2006-07 academic year, and currently has ten academic divisions.{{cite web | url=http://www.unikin.cd/index.php?page=facultes | title =Facultés | accessdate =December 15, 2010 | publisher =University of Kinshasa |language=fr}} ==Campus== The university is located about {{convert|15|km}} south of central Kinshasa, in the suburb of [[Lemba, Kinshasa|Lemba]]. Many of the campus facilities have deteriorated and are in poor condition, or lack proper instructional tools - in 2003, the science library had as few as 300 titles in its collection. Since 2001, the university has hosted Cisco Academy, a joint project sponsored by the American software company [[Cisco]] and the [[United Nations Development Programme]]. The academy focuses on providing recent technology, training students to install and operate computer networks and all coursework is online.{{Citation | title =Light in the Harvard of darkness | newspaper =Economist | pages =41 | date =July 5, 2003 }} ==History== ===Lovanium University=== The university was established in 1954 as [[Lovanium University]] by Belgian colonial authorities following criticism that they had done too little to educate the Congolese people. The university was originally affiliated with the [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Catholic University of Leuven]] in Belgium. When it opened, the university received heavy subsidies from the colonial government {{Cite book | last =World Bank | title =Education In the Democratic Republic of Congo | publisher =World Bank Publications | year =2005 | location =Washington, D.C. | pages =102–122 | isbn =9780821361214}} and funding from the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Rockefeller Foundation]] and the [[United States Agency for International Development]] and was lauded as the best university in Africa.{{Cite news | last = Greenhouse | first = Steven | title = Kinshasa Journal; Hunger Competes With a Thirst for Knowledge | pages = Section A; Page 4, Column 3; Foreign Desk | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York | date = June 2, 1988 }} ===National University of Zaire=== [[File:Université de Kinshasa.JPG|Rectorat|thumb|The ''Rectorat'', main administrative building at the University of Kinshasa]] In August 1971, the university was merged with the ''Protestant Autonomous University of Congo'' (''Université Libre du Congo'') and ''The University of Congo at Lubumbashi'' (founded in 1956) into the [[University of Zaire|''National University of Zaire'']] (Université Nationale du Zaïre, UNAZA). Ties were cut with the Catholic University of Leuven, and funding for the university began to drop precipitously. At this point, the university had an enrollment capacity of just 5,000. The decision to merge the private universities into one centralized system was made, at least partially, to counter concerns about political demonstrations on campuses. The entire higher education system was run by a single rector and faculty and staff were put on the federal payroll. By 1981, the centralized system became too burdensome and the decision was made to re-establish the three separate institutions: the University of Kinshasa, [[Kisangani University]], and the [[University of Lubumbashi]]. ===Decline in funding=== Newly independent, the University of Kinshasa continued to struggle financially throughout the 1980s. By 1985, the campus was in decline, strewn with trash and the dormitories in poor condition. The university's cafeteria stopped serving meals and pay for professors slipped as low as $15. In response to declining government funds tuition was raised 500 percent in 1985,{{Cite news | last = Greenhouse | first = Steven | title = 18 Months of Harsh Austerity Bring Indications of a Turnaround to Zaire; High Price Exacted By Lauded Reforms | pages =First Section; A23 | newspaper = The Washington Post | location = Washington, D.C. | date = May 22, 1985 }} and in 1989, deeper cuts were made, with the suspension of nearly all scholarships and financial aid and institution of new fees. Through the 1980s, as much as 90 percent of the university's budget was paid for by the government, with only a small amount of revenues coming from student tuition. By 2002, the government only contributed $8,000 (USD) of the university's estimated $4.3 million annual budget (not including some personnel costs which are paid directly by the state). == Nuclear Reactor == {{Main|Regional Center for Nuclear Studies}} The first nuclear reactor in Africa was built at the University of Kinshasa in 1958. The reactor, known as TRICO I, is a [[TRIGA]] reactor built by [[General Atomics]]. TRICO stands for a combination of TRIGA or “Training Isotopes General Atomic” and Congo.{{cite book|title=1952-2002 SCK•CEN|isbn=9076971056|url=http://www.sckcen.be/en/content/download/1259/27403/file/BrochureSCK50_UK.pdf}} The reactor was built while the country was still under Belgian control, and with the assistance of the United States government, under the [[Atoms For Peace]] program. TRIGA I was estimated to have a 50-kilowatt capacity and was shut down in 1970. In 1967, the African Union established a nuclear research center, the [[Regional Center for Nuclear Studies]] and the United States agreed to provide another TRIGA reactor. The second reactor, TRICO II, is believed to have a one-megawatt capacity and was brought online in 1972.{{cite web | url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/congo/index.html | title =Congo Special Weapons | accessdate =December 15, 2010 | publisher =globalsecurity.org }} In 2001, the TRICO II reactor was reported to be operational, but was apparently put on standby in 1998.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/nov/23/congo.chrismcgreal | title =Missing keys, holes in fence and a single padlock: welcome to Congo's nuclear plant | accessdate =December 15, 2010 | publisher =The Guardian | location=London | first=Chris | last=McGreal | date=November 23, 2006}} The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo stopped funding the program in the late 1980s, and the United States has since refused to ship replacement parts. International observers have long been concerned about the safety and security of the two nuclear reactors and the enriched uranium they contain. == Faculties and divisions == [[File:Profs unikin.JPG|thumb|Professors of the university in [[academic dress]]]] There are ten academic divisions at the university: * Faculty of Arts and Humanities * Faculty of Law * Faculty of Economics and Management * Faculty of Social Sciences Policy and Administrative * Faculty of Engineering * Faculty of Science ** The following subjects are available to study in the Faculty of Science: Physics, mathematics, biology, chemistry, geology. * Faculty of Agricultural Sciences * Faculty of Psychology and Educational Sciences * Faculty of Medicine **The following subjects are available to study in the faculty of medicine: biological medicine, physical medicine and dentistry. * Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://facmed-unikin.net/ Homepage of the University of Kinshasa] {{fr icon}} {{Portal bar|Democratic Republic of the Congo|University}} {{Authority control}} {{Coord|4|25|10|S|15|18|35|E|display=title|region:CD_type:edu_source:dewiki}} [[Category:Universities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Kinshasa]] [[Category:Education in Kinshasa]] [[Category:Schools in Kinshasa]] [[Category:1954 establishments in the Belgian Congo]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1954]]

{{Orphan|date=April 2014}}
'''Volunteer Eco Students Abroad''' (VESAbroad) is a non governamental organisation<ref>{{cite web|last=Volunteer Eco Students Abroad|title=Donations Page|url=http://www.vesabroad.com/make_a_donation.htm|publisher=VESAbroad.com|accessdate=2013-02-02}}</ref> founded in 2009 which has been established to give participants from around the globe the opportunity to visit a number of countries and to participate in a program consisting of some [[volunteer work]] and [[adventure tourism]]. The primary programs are generally of two weeks duration with opportunities to extend the trip with supplementary adventure tours.
==Programs== Split into two week-long sections, the program sees participants volunteering in areas of need such the areas of [[education]], [[construction]] and [[Conservation biology|conservation]] in a range of multi-faceted projects.
During the second week participants are accompanied on a tour of the country which comprises a number of adventurous and/or cultural activities. The programs are aimed at broadening the participant’s awareness of what these countries lack but also what they have to offer.
Some projects undertaken by VESAbroad volunteers include: *Refurbishing classrooms and [[water tank]]s at Vugalei District School in [[Naimasimasi]], [[Fiji]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Luvenitoga|first=Jone|title=Canadian volunteers at Vugalei school|url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?ref=archive&id=146453|publisher=The Fiji Times|accessdate=9/3/2011}}</ref> *Teaching and promoting hygiene in Biasevu Village School on [[Viti Levu Island]], Fiji.<ref>{{cite web|last=Strike|first=Michelle|title=The real Fiji life inspires Rachel|url=http://www.colliemail.com.au/news/local/news/general/the-real-fiji-life-inspires-rachel/2400876.aspx?storypage=0|publisher=Collie Mail|accessdate=9/3/2012}}</ref> *Teaching English and providing maintenance for the Puka Urku village in [[Ecuador]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Pearson|first=Matt|title=UWS student dedicated to human rights|url=http://penrith-press.whereilive.com.au/news/story/uws-student-dedicated-to-human-rights/|publisher=Penrith Press|accessdate=9/03/2012}}</ref> *Conservation work on [[cheetah]] and [[crocodile]] farms near [[Saint Lucia]], [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Strike|first=Michelle|title=Demi's African experience|url=http://www.colliemail.com.au/news/local/news/general/demis-african-experience/2393409.aspx|publisher=Collie Mail|accessdate=9/03/2012}}</ref> *A planned trip to Ecuador in 2012 will involve building and refurbishing a local school and building eco-friendly amenities for a local village.<ref>{{cite web|last=Armsberry|first=Jill|title=On a mission into Amazon|url=http://www.lakesmail.com.au/news/local/news/general/on-a-mission-into-amazon/2360037.aspx|publisher=Lakes Mail|accessdate=9/03/2012}}</ref>
